svcsection.title: AIR CONDITIONING BASIC THEORY, SYSTEM DIAGNOSIS AND SERVICE (WITH R-12 REFRIGERANT SYSTEM)

lev1.title: BASIC PRINCIPLES
lev1.para: To meet the Federal Government's scheduled phase-out of CFC-12 (R-12) refrigerant, International will start building vehicles charged with the new refrigerant HFC-134A on the following dates:

Vehicle air conditioning is the cooling or refrigeration of air in the passenger compartment ( Figure 1). Refrigeration is accomplished by the practical application of three laws of nature. These are: heat transfer, latent heat of vaporization, and pressure of vaporization.

lev2.title: HEAT TRANSFER

para.emph: When two substances of different temperatures are placed next to each other, the heat in the warmer substance will always travel to the colder substance until both are of equal temperature.

lev2.para: For example, the ice in a cold drink does not transfer its coldness to the beverage. The heat in the beverage transfers to the ice which has less heat. As the beverage transfers heat to the ice the beverage becomes cooler and the ice is converted to water. The unit used to measure heat transfer is the British Thermal Unit (BTU) and is the amount of heat required to raise the temperature of one pound (.454 kg) of water 1°F (.55°C).

lev2.title: LATENT HEAT OF VAPORIZATION
lev2.para: When a liquid boils (changes to gas), it absorbs heat without raising the temperature of the liquid or the resulting gas. When the gas condenses (changes back to a liquid), it gives off heat without lowering the temperature of the gas or resulting liquid.

Nature throws us a curve here. Once a liquid reaches its boiling point, it never gets any hotter regardless of how much more heat is added. A three-minute boiled egg will always take three minutes to cook regardless of how high you turn up the heat. What does happen is that as more heat is applied, the more rapidly the water is converted to vapor. Neither the temperature of the water or the vapor will exceed 212°F.

The excess heat that is used in the conversion of water to vapor is the "heat of vaporization" or latent heat. Latent is a Latin word meaning "hidden" or "concealed." The heat required to change the water to vapor remains hidden within the water molecules. The temperature of the vapor does not increase.

When the vapor is changed back to water, it is said to condense and the hidden heat in the molecules is absorbed by the surrounding air. The molecules are once again held together in a liquid state. This is what takes place in the condenser of an air conditioning system.

lev2.title: PRESSURE OF VAPORIZATION

para.emph: The saturation temperature (the temperature where boiling or condensation occurs) of a liquid or vapor increases or decreases according to the pressure exerted on it.

lev2.para: Going back to the example of the boiled egg which takes three minutes to cook at sea level where the boiling point of water is 212°F, the situation changes as we increase or decrease elevation. If we take a camping trip to the mountains, we will discover that our three-minute egg now takes much longer to cook because the decrease in air pressure at higher elevations allows water to boil at lower temperatures. If on the way home from the mountains we stop at Death Valley, which is below sea level, we will find our eggs cook in less than three minutes because the increase in air pressure causes the boiling point temperature of water to increase.

A more common example of the effect of high pressure on the boiling point of water, and all liquids for that matter, is the radiator in truck cooling systems. As the coolant warms, the pressure increases inside the sealed system. Because of the higher pressure inside the system, the boiling point of the coolant rises above 212°F. As long as the system remains sealed and pressure maintained, the coolant will not boil. If the radiator cap is removed, however, pressure in the system is rapidly reduced to the ambient air pressure and the coolant immediately boils over.

lev2.title: BASIC REFRIGERATION
lev2.para: With these basic ground rules: 1. All liquids absorb quantities of heat without getting any warmer when they boil into a vapor and 2. Pressure can then be used to make a vapor condense back into a liquid so that it can be used over again, we have the knowledge to build a basic air conditioning or refrigeration system.

International air conditioning systems use R-12 and HFC-134A refrigerant. The refrigerant boils at -15.7°F. at sea level. As pressure is increased, the boiling point of the refrigerant is raised well above the temperatures encountered on the hottest days. The low boiling point plus the fact that R-12 and HFC-134A can be cycled through the system nearly an endless number of times without loss of efficiency makes them ideal refrigerants.
Due to the difference in density between R-12 and HFC-134A, the amount of HFC-134A refrigerant required to charge a typical air conditioning system has been reduced from 4.5 lbs. to 3.5 lbs.

The ideal temperature for the refrigerant to boil is 30°F. Systems are designed to keep their pressure so the refrigerant boils at about this temperature. This creates the right temperature for taking the heat out of the cab. If it were any colder, the condensation in the evaporator would freeze, and if any warmer, the cooling would be inefficient.

lev2.title: HOW THE SYSTEM WORKS
lev2.para: If we start at the evaporator (Item 11, Figure 2), the refrigerant has taken on heat from the cab and changed to low pressure vapor. Even though it has taken on great quantities of heat from the cab, it is still only about 30°F. The outside air will range anywhere from 60°F to 100°F and the refrigerant must somehow be cooled before it can condense back into a liquid.

8. BLEND AIR DOOR AND AIR DUCTS

lev2.para: The answer to our problem is the compressor. It takes the refrigerant vapor and squeezes it into a smaller space, concentrating the heat it contains. This makes the vapor hotter without adding any heat. The refrigerant can now pass on to the condenser as a high pressure vapor and pass heat off to the relatively colder outside air and condense back to a liquid.

As the now liquid refrigerant leaves the condenser it flows to the receiver/dehydrator which strains the refrigerant and removes any moisture. The liquid refrigerant is passed from here to the expansion valve where it arrives at a high pressure, 100 to 250 psi. The expansion valve has two jobs. It meters the amount of refrigerant passing to the evaporator and lowers the pressure of the refrigerant so it can enter the evaporator at that ideal 30°F boiling point, take on heat from the cab and repeat the cycle.

lev2.title: COMPRESSOR
lev2.para: The compressor is a two-cylinder, reciprocating unit with a magnetic clutch pulley drive. It is mounted on the engine and belt-driven ( Figure 3).

calloutgroup.callout1: 3. PORT CAPS (KEEP IN PLACE WHEN LINES ARE DISCONNECTED)

lev2.para: It receives evaporated refrigerant at a pressure of 12 to 50 psi and increases it to 120-300 psi depending on surrounding air temperature and compressor speed.
Refer to AIR CONDITIONING COMPRESSOR AND CLUTCH Service Manual Sections in GROUP 16 of the CTS-5000 Master Service Manual for greater detail on these units.
The label on the clutch side of the compressor ( Figure 3) will list type of refrigerant and oil used in the system and the refrigerant charge quantity recommended by International.

lev2.title: REFRIGERANT OIL
lev2.para: The type of refrigerant oil used in HFC-134A charged systems has been changed to a non-mineral base oil. The following information must be adhered to when servicing air conditioning systems.

important.para: The refrigerant oil used in R-12 charged air conditioning systems CANNOT be used in HFC-134A charged air conditioning systems. The oil used in HFC-134A charged air conditioning systems CANNOT be used in R-12 charged air conditioning systems.

lev2.para: If you put the wrong oil in the system you are servicing, the system will function poorly and the life of the compressor will be drastically reduced.

caution.para: Keep spare HFC-134A refrigerant oil in a sealed container. The oil draws moisture and will become moisture contaminated if exposed to the atmosphere for any period of time.

important.para: DO NOT use oil approved for HFC-134A air conditioning systems to lubricate fittings and O-rings on R-12 or HFC-134A systems. The oil absorbs too much moisture which may corrode the fittings and make them difficult to disassemble. Use mineral-based oil (R-12 oil) to lubricate fittings and O-rings on both systems.

lev2.title: SYSTEM HOSES
lev2.para: Hoses used with HFC-134A charged air conditioning systems are smaller in diameter than hoses used on R-12 charged air conditioning systems. When servicing HFC-134A air conditioning systems, use only replacement hoses approved for HFC-134A air conditioning systems.

lev2.title: CONDENSER
lev2.para: The air conditioning condenser ( Figure 4) is located at the front of the vehicle between the engine radiator and the grille. The condenser receives high pressure, high temperature refrigerant gas from the compressor.

As the hot refrigerant gas flows through the condenser, it releases heat to the air passing over the fins. The cooler, compressed refrigerant gas condenses to a liquid, then flows through the receiver/dehydrator, expansion valve, evaporator and back to the compressor suction port.

lev2.title: RECEIVER/DEHYDRATOR
lev2.para: The receiver/dehydrator ( Figure 5) absorbs any moisture and filters any foreign particles from the system refrigerant. The unit also serves as a reservoir for storing liquid refrigerant, making it available as the system requires.

calloutgroup.callout1: 5. HIGH PRESSURE RELIEF VALVE (HFC-134A) (SERVICE DRYERS ONLY)

lev2.para: System protection is provided by a direct-acting high pressure relief valve that will discharge refrigerant into the atmosphere if the pressure exceeds the system limit. This is not a fusible plug and does not expel the entire charge. Relief pressure ranges from 450 psi to 600 psi depending on the particular system.

The receiver-dryer used on HFC-134A charged air conditioning systems has different desiccant material. On new vehicles, the pressure relief valve has been moved from the receiver-dryer to the refrigerant compressor. Replacement receiver-dryers furnished by International will have the pressure relief valve on the receiver-dryer. The receiver-dryer used in production will be equipped with a service port.

important.para: DO NOT use a receiver- dryer designed for use on an R-12 charged air conditioning system on an HFC-134A charged air conditioning system. The desiccant material will break down and plug the system. The receiver- dryer designed for use on an HFC-134A charged air conditioning system CAN be used on an R-12 charged air conditioning system. The receiver-dryer provided by International service parts will service both systems.

lev2.para: The receiver/dehydrator is located on the discharge (high pressure) side of the system between the condenser and expansion valve.

lev2.title: EVAPORATOR CORE
lev2.para: The evaporator core is a radiator-like core ( Figure 6). The line from the expansion valve connects at the bottom of the core. The suction line is connected at the top. Refrigerant is sprayed into the evaporator as a low temperature, low pressure liquid. The refrigerant absorbs heat through the plates and fins of the evaporator and becomes a gas. The now warm vapor is pulled from the evaporator through the suction line by the compressor.

lev2.title: EXPANSION VALVE
lev2.para: The expansion valve ( Figure 7) is located between the receiver/dehydrator and the evaporator, and regulates the flow of refrigerant entering the evaporator.
Leaving the expansion valve, the refrigerant starts to expand, entering the evaporator as a low pressure, low temperature liquid.

Attached to the top of the expansion valve is a capillary tube with a feeler bulb which is clamped to the outlet (suction) pipe of the evaporator. The sealed bulb and tube are filled with gas that expands and contracts according to temperature surrounding the bulb. The feeler bulb senses the temperature of refrigerant leaving the evaporator.

A second capillary tube is attached under the valve diaphragm and is connected to the evaporator outlet (suction) pipe. This is an equalizer line which senses suction pressure. Together, they regulate the amount of refrigerant entering the evaporator.

The expansion valve used on HFC-134A charged air conditioning systems is different than the valve used on R-12 charged air conditioning systems. The capillary tube and sensing bulb are filled with HFC-134A.

important.para: DO NOT USE an expansion valve designed for use on an HFC-134A charged air conditioning system on an R-12 charged air conditioning system. DO NOT USE an expansion valve designed for use on an R-12 charged air conditioning system on an HFC-134A charged air conditioning system.

lev2.title: THERMOSTATIC CONTROL SWITCH
lev2.para: The thermostatic control switch ( Figure 8) is a thermal device that controls an electrical switch. A connected refrigerant-filled capillary tube is inserted in the fins and tubes of the evaporator core. The capillary tube is attached to a bellows inside the thermostat, which in turn closes a set of contacts at a pre-determined temperature. When the capillary tube senses 45°F (7°C.), the thermostat closes sending current to the magnetic clutch engaging the compressor. When the capillary tube senses 34°F (2°C.), the thermostat switch opens, disengaging the magnetic clutch so the evaporator does not freeze up and stop air flowing through it. Blend Air units in the 5000 and 9000 Series vehicles have a manually adjustable thermostatic control switch. All other vehicles are automatic as described above.

lev2.title: REFRIGERANT LOW PRESSURE SWITCH
lev2.para: A low pressure switch ( Figure 9) is used to protect the compressor. It is located in the refrigerant return line and prevents compressor operation if the ambient temperature is too low. The low pressure also prevents compressor operation if the refrigerant level is too low. Low refrigerant also means low lubricant and can result in compressor damage.

figure.caption: Figure 9. Refrigerant Low and High Pressure Switch

lev2.para: The switch is normally closed. When the system operates, normal system pressure holds the switch open. If system low pressure (compressor suction) gets too low, the switch closes, energizing a relay that opens the circuit to the compressor magnetic clutch and stops operation of the compressor.

lev2.title: HIGH PRESSURE SAFETY SWITCH
lev2.para: A high pressure safety switch has been added to HFC-134A air conditioning systems. The high pressure switch will disengage the A/C clutch when abnormally high pressures (375 psi ± 20 psi) are reached. Refer to the air conditioning service section for the vehicle being serviced for the location of the switch.

lev2.title: FAN DRIVE AND RADIATOR SHUTTER OVERRIDE SWITCHES
lev2.para: Vehicles with an engine cooling fan clutch have a fan drive switch located in the refrigerant compressor service port ( Figure 10).

figure.caption: Figure 10. Fan Drive and Radiator Shutter Override Switches

calloutgroup.callout1: 1. FAN DRIVE OR SHUTTER OVERRIDE SWITCH

lev2.para: When the compressor discharge pressure exceeds the high pressure limit, this switch is activated and the engine fan drive clutch engages to provide maximum air flow through the condenser. The fan remains engaged until the compressor discharge pressure falls below the low pressure limit ( Figure 10). There are several types of fan drives and each has a specific switch and valve combination. For more detailed information, refer to GROUP 12, ENGINE in the CTS-5000 Master Service Manual.

Vehicles equipped with radiator shutters have a pressure switch also located in the refrigerant compressor discharge line. It is identical in appearance to the fan drive switch, but is set to operate at different pressure levels.

The radiator shutters are held open by spring pressure and are closed by an air cylinder working against the spring(s). The switch operates a solenoid valve that shuts off the compressed air to the cylinder and allows the spring(s) to open the shutters.

lev2.title: FAN DRIVE AND RADIATOR SHUTTER SOLENOID VALVES
lev2.para: The fan clutches and radiator shutters are operated by compressed air. The air is controlled by solenoid valves that are operated by the pressure switches. The valves are all of the same construction ( Figure 11), but have different operating characteristics depending on the system where they are installed.

figure.caption: Figure 11. Fan Drive and Radiator Shutter Solenoid Shutter Valves
